text: The paper investigates influence functions and curriculum learning. It explores different layer configurations for influence function computation and applies curriculum learning within a multi-armed bandit framework.
The paper uses established influence function methods (ABIF, TracIn) and curriculum learning techniques.

The paper proposes a method for improving model performance in the presence of noisy training data using self-influence and bandit curriculum learning. The method aims to detect and address outliers in NLP datasets.
The paper acknowledges the problem of noisy data in NLP and proposes a method to address it. The limitations section discusses the computational cost of the approach.
The paper lacks a thorough discussion of potential risks, including misuse, fairness, and broader societal impacts. There is no explicit discussion of ethical considerations.

Include a section on potential misuses of the proposed method, such as its application to generate biased or misleading information. Discuss how the method could be used to amplify existing biases in the data.

Analyze the fairness implications of the method. Consider how the method might affect different demographic groups if applied to datasets containing sensitive information. Discuss potential biases in the data and how the method might exacerbate them.

Expand the limitations section to include a discussion of the societal scope constraints of the research. Consider the potential for the method to be used for malicious purposes, such as generating fake news or manipulating public opinion.

The societal scope is limited by the focus on improving model performance in the presence of noisy training data. The potential for misuse, fairness concerns, and broader societal impacts are not adequately addressed.

The paper builds upon the work of Feldman and Zhang (2020) [1] by using self-influence scores for data cleaning. It extends this by investigating the efficacy of these scores in capturing outliers and improving downstream performance across multiple tasks (machine translation, question answering, and text classification).

The paper addresses the limitations of filtering methods by employing automated curriculum learning (Graves et al., 2017; Kreutzer et al., 2021) to learn effective training schedules, which is inspired by the work of Swayamdipta et al. (2020) [3] and Nguyen et al. (2020) [2].

The paper does not explicitly compare the performance of its proposed method with the self-ensembling approach of Nguyen et al. (2020) [2] or the dataset cartography approach of Swayamdipta et al. (2020) [3].

Conduct a head-to-head comparison with Nguyen et al. (2020) [2] and Swayamdipta et al. (2020) [3] on the same datasets used in the current paper (machine translation, question answering, and text classification). Evaluate the performance on both in-distribution and out-of-distribution test sets to assess generalization.

The paper does not provide a detailed analysis of the differences in performance between using self-influence scores and other data cleaning methods, such as those based on confidence scores or label noise detection.

Include an ablation study comparing the proposed method with a baseline that uses confidence scores or label noise detection for data cleaning. This will help to isolate the contribution of self-influence scores.
